author: Morgan Housel
summary: History is mostly the study of surprising events, yet it's often used as a map of the future. The most important economic events are things that history gives us little guide about - they will be unprecedented. Things that have never happened before happen all the time.
key_takeaways: Things that have never happened before happen all the time.
The correct lesson from surprises is that the world is surprising.
The further back in history you look, the more general your takeaways should be.

questions.question: What is the 'historians as prophets' fallacy in investing?

options.text: Believing historians make good financial advisors
Over-relying on past data as a signal for future conditions
Thinking ancient civilizations had better economies
Ignoring all historical data when making decisions

questions.explanation: The 'historians as prophets' fallacy is an overreliance on past data as a signal to future conditions in a field where innovation and change are the lifeblood of progress.

questions.question: What is the correct lesson to learn when you're surprised by an event you didn't anticipate?

options.text: Study that specific event to never be surprised by it again
The world is surprising, and you have no idea what might happen next
You should avoid all risky situations

questions.explanation: As Daniel Kahneman said: when you make a mistake because you didn't anticipate something, the correct lesson is that the world is difficult to anticipate - not to use that surprise as a guide to future boundaries.

questions.question: Why do Benjamin Graham's specific investment formulas from the 1970s NOT work well today?

options.text: Graham was a fraud who never actually used them
The economy, markets, and competition have structurally changed over time

questions.explanation: Graham constantly discarded and replaced his formulas because things changed. Competition grew, technology made information accessible, and industries shifted. The S&P 500 didn't even include tech stocks 50 years ago.
